text: good morning CubeCon let me start by
introducing myself my name is Jabed i'm
from a company called Cortex where I
spend most of my time working very
closely with um engineering teams across

from different functions from platform
engineering security sur infrastructure
IT and so on which puts me in a a very
lucky position to be in where I get to
learn from all of these people in terms
of what are the problems that they're
trying to solve how do they go about
solving them uh what are they struggling
to solve and so today I'll be talking
about how many of these companies are
adopting a product management mindset to
build better platform and drive
developer
experience should have picked up the uh
slide
advancer so two themes to start with
platform engineers build the foundations
of engineering
excellence and the goal of product
management is to solve customer needs in
service of business outcomes so by the
end of this we want to see how both of
these practices converge to make for a
better platform but first let's start by
defining engineering excellence so
through all of these conversations
there's a very common theme in terms of
what engineering leaders are tasked to
solve and the business outcomes that
they need to drive which typically fall
into the following three
buckets well start with one unlocking
innovation and reducing time to
market lowering cost increasing
efficiency improving quality and
customer experience so how does an
engineering team contribute to and
accelerate that and that's where we
start to define the four pillars of
engineering
excellence which are
velocity
efficiency security and
reliability now you'll notice that these
initiatives translate very well to the
different functions that exist across an
entire engineering organization but who
is really in a position to connect and
enable all of
that and that's platform engineering
platform engineers build the foundations
of engineering excellence so let's now
bring product management into the mix
and but let's first look at some of the
common failure modes where can it go
wrong and what to avoid um which are
seemingly obvious things like assuming
customer needs or prioritizing outputs
over outcomes uh ignoring stakeholder
ecosystems ignoring user feedback and of
course trying to build too much at once
now whilst platform engineers are
serving a very different customer
fundamentally many of these pitfalls can
still very easily apply so if we now
flip that on its head and bring the best
product management principles to
platform
engineering then we have platform as a
product where we anticipate developer
needs so instead of managing fe feature
requests and asking what to build it's a
question of what's working and what's
not what are the bottlenecks that are
preventing us from achieving those four
pillars of engineering
excellence designing for all personas so
developers have to satisfy many
different stakeholders across the
engineering team many different
functions like security S infrastructure
and so on so can we build platform in a
way that incorporates all of those teams
and their needs from the get-go and
gives developers a single entry point to
satisfy everyone
then of course prioritizing business
outcomes so are we focusing on high
impact pain
points that came out of the research for
example reducing onboarding time from
weeks down to days or reducing the time
it takes to provision new services or
spin up new infrastructure
and then of course do we have the right
feedback loops in place to communicate
with our
developers and build iteratively and
deliver incremental value rather than
trying to build everything at once and
of course are we measuring success with
the right KPIs and metrics so whether
it's using Dora metrics for
understanding the technical aspects of
software delivery performance or space
metrics for a more holistic view
um and of course adoption are developers
actually using what we build are they
getting value from it is it saving them
time or is it causing more
friction now companies are adopting this
mindset using an internal developer
portal
and they have complete visibility across
their entire software estate through
integrated cataloges for services
infrastructure their teams for clear
ownership uh they're using scorecards to
be able to measure those metrics we
talked about in real time set benchmarks
against those set standards so that
developers know exactly how to satisfy
those crossunctional needs and then of
course providing safe self-service so
workflows to automate complex and manual
tasks giving developers time back to do
what they do best which is code now this
is of particular interest to companies
who are looking to lower the total cost
of ownership of their platform and drive
a faster time to value for their
platform which just so happens to be
